title: Monday, 15th May, 2017

PM11:05am

The project is led by a group called Cartivator. It all started in 2012 when project leader Tsubasa Nakamura won a business contest -- not an internal one. Its 30-odd members donate their free time. They have also received some outside help -- from Masafumi Miwa, a drone expert and associate professor of mechanical engineering at Tokushima University, and Taizo Son, founder of GungHo Online Entertainment, a Japanese online video game developer.

Toyota and its group companies have agreed, in principle, to provide some 40 million yen ($352,982) to Cartivator, which has so far relied on online crowdfunding and other means for financing.

BE11:13am

BE11:13am

Very cautious and slow recovery as the recent beating down of prices has forced a great number of speculative longs from the market. They will need real convincing that U.S. inventory levels are going sharply lower before wading back into the market in big numbers. This could require several more weekly reports similar in strength to the most recently reported. The fundamental data continues to point to a slowly tightening U.S. crude oil market and crude oil inventory levels look set to drop below year-ago levels within the next few weeks. Such an outcome would be the first year-over-year crude oil inventory deficit since 2014 and appears to be on track given the still very high run rates for refiners; these are expected to be sustained well into the summer months. Lastly, the likelihood is very high that OPEC and select Non-OPEC Producers will extend their production cutting agreement for the remainder of the year at the next meeting on May 25. However, we do not see a strong likelihood of the cuts being deepened. A basic extension of cuts to the end of the year should be more than able to bring about deeper global inventory reductions in 2H17.

PM11:17am

Billiton’s roots trace back to 1851 and a tin mine on a little known island in Indonesia, Billiton (Belitung) island. Billiton became a global leader in the metals and mining sector and a major producer of aluminium and alumina, chrome and manganese ores and alloys, steaming coal, nickel and titanium minerals. Billiton also developed a substantial and growing copper portfolio.

11:18 am
PM11:18am

Billiton older than BHP

PM11:18am

Broken Hill Proprietary’s rich history began in a silver, lead and zinc mine in Broken Hill, Australia. Incorporated in 1885, BHP engaged in the discovery, development, production and marketing of iron ore, copper, oil and gas, diamonds, silver, lead, zinc and a range of other natural resources. BHP was also a market leader in value-added flat steel products.

PM11:18am

http://www.bhpbill...proach/our-history

11:18 am
BE11:19am

I'm not sure that's how it works. I mean, Xstrata was founded before the war.

BE11:19am

And its name was ditched about 15 minutes after Glencore bought.

BE11:19am

Anyway ....

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Citi's doing the breakup theory on BHP this morning

BE11:20am

Their idea is rather more than "change the letterheads"

BE11:20am

We think the current period of shareholder activism could result in a breakup and/or a significant alteration of the company’s structure. In the short term we believe the most value accretive option would be to spin-off the entire Petroleum business, but in the longer term, the company would still need to demonstrate a pathway to grow value. With the shares trading at a 31% discount to our calculated SOTP, we maintain our BUY rating and £14.50 price target.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

We think it would be wrong to focus purely on a “breakup” or asset disposal situation, as we think this would be a once-off, short-term and short-lived event. We think the key long-term issue is how the company can ‘grow value’. We believe the debate needs to shift to growing EVA or NPV per share rather than just growing volumes. The key issue in our mind is that, on our forecasts, we have the company delivering a less than 10% ROIC, has around 50% of its asset base delivering ROAs below 5%. Even looking out until 2020 this picture doesn’t appear to improve materially

BE11:21am

The company has improved operational performance and implemented its strategy efficiently but we question whether the current strategy is going to be effective in delivering a rerating. BHPB has now derated to the lowest Price to Book and EV/IC multiples since 1982. We continue to stand by our note of 2012 in which we argued that BHPB needed to SHRINK, SPIN and GROW, while the company has spun S32 we think it still needs to Slim and Grow.

BE11:21am

The move to spot iron ore, thermal and met coal pricing may have resulted in a c$27bn market derating

While the average price of commodities is likely to be the same under spot versus annual pricing, the introduction of daily pricing has significantly increased the volatility of earnings, cashflow, dividends and therefore valuations outcomes. In our view the biggest change has been a significant rise in the company’s beta, making it harder for fund managers seeking alpha, to invest in the company while holding the volatility. However, we think there is a pathway for the company as it needs to optimize its portfolio, shrink assets run with lower debt levels and actively manage volatility to lower its cost of capital, which ultimately could drive a bigger rerating than simply spinning petroleum or selling US onshore.

11:21 am
PM11:21am

"We continue to stand by our note of 2012"

PM11:21am

hmm

BE11:22am

Lonmin PLC (LMI:LSE): Last: 105.50, down 6.75 (-6.01%), High: 115.00, Low: 101.75, Volume: 1.42m
11:23 am

Got no money and not producing enough.

11:24 am
PM11:24am

PM11:24am

BE11:25am

11:25 am
BE11:25am

And if it's obvious to us .... I mean .....

hehehe

BE11:25am

So, it's had operational pretty decent an a platinum price rally, and it's still living hand to mouth.

11:25 am
BE11:26am

Here's RBC.

BE11:26am

Our take: Q1/FY17E was very poor for Lonmin operationally; Q2 production has shown signs of improvement qoq, with month on month production and cost improvements (the operations were cash negative in the quarter with a basket price of ZAR11,250/oz vs. costs of ZAR11,826/oz, although March costs were ZAR9,695/oz). If performance similar to March is sustainable, this is encouraging, although April was likely to be impacted by the Easter break, and community issues are likely to have hampered May production slightly. The impacts of a weak Q1 have resulted in an increase in cost guidance to ZAR11,300/oz-ZAR11,800/oz (from ZAR10,800/oz-ZAR11,300/oz) and the company has cut its capex guidance to ZAR1.4bn-ZAR1.5bn (from ZAR1.8bn); this is likely to heighten concerns that the company is under-investing in the Marikana ore body. Further, a US$146m impairment at Marikana has resulted in the Tangible Net Worth covenant (of US$1.1bn) coming into focus (it was US$1.434bn at end-March). This has resulted in Lonmin flagging a risk of covenant breach and a Going Concern paragraph in the results. This is a concern and once again brings the balance sheet back into focus. While the signs of operational turnaround are encouraging, we expect balance sheet concerns to weigh on sentiment this morning, tempered in part by better spot PGM prices. Other points to note include the plan to move its head office to Marikana from Johannesburg, and a deal with Northam to acquire the 7.5% of Pandora that it does not already own (assuming the purchase of 42.5% of the asset from AngloPlat completes) for ZAR45.565m (US$3.4m) in cash. The main driver of this deal appears to be the ability to defer ZAR1.6bn of capex in 2018-20, and ~ZAR1bn thereafter. The shares are trading at 7.22x NAV, 3.3x FY18E CF and 3.0x FY18E EV/EBITDA.

BE11:26am

Results below RBC on impairment and working cap moves: Q2 refined production of 164koz Pt was slightly behind our 170koz estimate, while sales of 172koz came in ahead of our 163koz. Q2 costs of ZAR11,836 (improving from a poor ZAR15,979/oz in January to ZAR9,695/oz in March) compared to a basket price of ZAR11,250/oz. H1 revenues of US$486m were in line with our US$481m, with EBITDA of nil was in line with our US$2m estimate. A US$146m impairment drove a loss of US$214m (attrib: US$182m, or US$0.64/sh), vs. RBC at -US$27m (-US$0.10/sh). CFO of -US$48m was below our –US$5m driven mainly by a US$61 m negative working capital movement, (RBC: -US$12m), and helped by a US$26m deferred revenue receipt related to the Bulk Tailings project. Capex of US$44m lagged our US$72m estimate, and US$4m of debt was drawn (RBC: nil). LMI ended March with cash of US$229m (RBC: US$246m), and net cash of US$75m (RBC: US$96m).

11:26 am
PM11:26am

Holding above a quid for now

PM11:26am

And it's been substantially lower

BE11:26am

Bear in mind that a quid is a penny in old money.

11:26 am
PM11:27am

But was looking back at the chart -- factoring in the consoidations etc, this was trading at 26,000 ten years ago

BE11:27am

Ben Davis at Liberum's still a seller.

BE11:27am

Interim results saw zero EBITDA for the first half (Sept y/e), and cash was down to $75m from $173m in the six months. There was improvement in Q2 on a disastorous Q1, and Lonmin have maintained sale guidance as they believe "decisive action" of delayering will ensure better production performance for the remainder of the year. Lonmin have had to raise cost guidance to R11,300-R11,8000/oz from R10,800-R11/300/oz. Capex has been lowered by R400m, unclear where this has come out from. The tangible net worth covenant (can not be less than $1,100m) is approaching, falling from $1,917m in Mar'16, to $1,608m, $1,434m at this reporting period. At the current PGM Rand basket, Lonmin has to have a very good second half to stay cash neutral, although we know they are already suffering from community protests current and losing production as some minor shafts. Continues to offer option value for the bulls but risks are still strongly against it.

BE11:31am

Petrofac mentioned earlier. Not a whole lot to add really.

11:31 am
Petrofac Ltd (PFC:LSE): Last: 687.36, down 12.64 (-1.81%), High: 696.50, Low: 671.00, Volume: 2.21m
BE11:31am

The news -- not unexpected I thought? -- of the SFO probe was too late for us on Friday.

BE11:32am

Here's UBS.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

On Friday, UK's Serious Fraud Office (SFO) announced it launched an investigation into Petrofac for bribery, corruption and money laundering related to the SFO's investigation of Unaoil. Unaoil is a Monaco-based firm - in spring 2016, there were media reports alleging numerous multinational companies had used Unaoil to make illegal payments to secure work. In August 2016, Petrofac announced that its own independent investigation found no evidence confirming the payment of bribes. It also confirmed that no evidence was found that any Director was aware of the alleged misconduct. Petrofac shared its findings of the investigation with the SFO and other relevant authorities. At the time, Petrofac confirmed that it engaged Unaoil for the provision of local consultancy services primarily in Kazakhstan between 2002 and 2009. The findings of the investigation were also published in its 2016 annual report. Petrofac said it is cooperating with authorities.

BE11:32am

Although Petrofac's previous involvement with Unaoil was already in the public domain prior to the SFO's announcement, nonetheless the announcement triggered risk aversion and Petrofac shares traded down sharply, wiping out ~£400m ($500m) of market cap. To put this into context - we estimate that the single largest contract in Kazakhstan for Petrofac was for the provision of process facilities for the Kashagan project, awarded back in August 2004. Although not disclosed, we estimated at the time the contract value was in the range of $400-500m. Subsequently, there were numerous contracts in Kazakhstan for front end engineering and design and project management work. In 2008 and 2009, Petrofac disclosed revenues in Kazakhstan were $200m and $184m, respectively, accounting for ~5% of group revenue (revenues less than 2007 were included in the CIS region). From 2010 onwards, the revenues in Kazakstan were not sufficiently material for separate disclosure.

BE11:33am

Our experience tells us that these legal matters take a long time to resolve and the potential financial impact is almost impossible to estimate from the outside as all parties are reluctant to discuss details. There could be a rebound in the shares as investors shift their focus more to improving order intake, cashflow generation and reducing capital intensity.

11:33 am
PM11:33am

I always thought it weird the way the Unaoil disclosures seemed to go quiet

PM11:33am

Did they threaten everyone with legal action? (perhaps, genuinely not sure)

BE11:34am

Not sure. I also thought Petrofac had been pretty clear about its use of Unaoil in previous statements, but it seems to have surprised people nevertheless.

11:35 am

The relevance of the chart above is to understand the historical reality of meeting 2018 and 2019 revenue estimates from current backlog positions (YE16). We estimate at least $4bn of new lump-sum E&C backlog additions (awards or variation orders) are required during 2017 to support our group revenue estimates for 2017, 18 and 19. So far this year PFC has announced c.$2bn of awards. Historically, the company has achieved more than $4bn of new awards in four of the of the past seven years.

BE11:37am

......... and winning big contracts ain't easy when the C-suite's being interviewed under caution by the SFO.

BE11:41am

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Quick summary from Cenkos.

BE11:41am

TUI GROUP (TUI LN, 1190p, £7.0bn mkt cap, Hold) has announced a 12.2% widening in constant currency H1 underlying EBITA to €214.3m. There was a strong performance from Hotels & Resorts, up 31.0% and Cruises up 58.5% but the operating losses in Source Markets widened by c1/3 predominantly reflecting the shift in the timing of Easter (€38m impact) and TUIfly sickness (€24m impact). Merger synergies contributed a €10m benefit. Net debt at the period end was €1.4bn, down 11% YOY. Summer 2017 trading remains in line with expectations with the Source Markets programme 62% sold, in line with the prior year. Bookings are up 4% and average selling prices (ASP) up 5%, to leave revenue up 9% YOY. Bookings via the direct and online channels are up 4% and 6% respectively. Demand from the UK remains resilient with bookings flat YOY and 5% growth in ASP, partly reflecting currency cost inflation for Euro-based destinations. The group has therefore reiterated its FY 2017 guidance of at least 10% growth in constant currency underlying EBITA. We therefore expect no material change to consensus expectations of €1,111m EBITA (Cenkos €1,104m). This leaves the stock trading on a FY 2017E P/E of 13.0x, which appears high enough given the uncertain macro-economic and political backdrop whilst the attractive 4.6% yield provides solid support.

BE11:42am

And a bit of a grumble about underlying trends from Bernstein.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

UK Marginal bookings look weak. UK Bookings at the March pre-close announcement were up 3% for Summer 2017, two months later Summer bookings are only up 1% (despite the launch of a new cruise ship), implying bookings in April and May are down 8% year on year. Perhaps early signs of a Brexit caused squeeze?

BE11:42am

Group wide booking remain at +4% for summer. Outside of the UK, the situation is more positive. Bookings in Benelux have materially accelerated in the last 2 months and are also up in Germany. Overall bookings are up 4% for the summer and prices up 5%.

Q2 results show a widening loss, but caused mainly by Easter. Q2 is always a loss making quarter, but this loss widened from -€126m to -€157m, however a later Easter was a €38m drag on results; excluding this, the loss slightly contracted aided by increasing contribution from cruises and hotels (which are less seasonal).

BE11:44am

Oh, yes, there's also the mass pilot lurgy.

BE11:45am

11:45 am
BE11:46am

PM11:46am

Thought we were trying to keep the session cyber terror free?

BE11:46am

11:46 am
Sophos Group PLC (SOPH:LSE): Last: 367.50, up 26.3 (+7.71%), High: 368.40, Low: 345.50, Volume: 1.54m
PM11:47am

Actually, we use Sophos here at the FT

PM11:48am

Or our colleagues in IT do

11:48 am
BE11:48am

We do. Endpoint. It makes your PC really slow.

BE11:49am

Anyway, Sophos has numbers on Friday.

BE11:49am

Giving us another chance to grump about its makey-up measures of profitability.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

As in, Cash EBITDA.

BE11:49am

Here's Deutsche.

BE11:49am

SOPH reports FY17 results BMO on May 17th. The company released a trading statement on April 4th, stating that FY17 CC billings grew 20% to ~$630m and Cash EBITDA and uFCF would be ahead of prev guidance. We believe that midteens billings growth is achievable in FY18. We forecast FY17 billings of $630m, cash EBITDA of $154m and uFCF of $115m. We increase our TP to 350p based on FY18E multiples which are in line with key US peers on a CY18E EV/uFCF basis (cheaper ex stock-based comp), yet SOPH offers superior billings and FCF growth.

11:49 am
BE11:50am

Strong momentum in Endpoint
The Q4 trading update suggested Sophos continues to execute well – billings grew 27% with strength in Endpoint (greater than 30%), reflecting momentum from Intercept X. Going forward, the Invincea acquisition (machine learning based Endpoint) should help SOPH gain market share in this space. Sophos Central (security dashboard driving improved performance between End User and Network) was also called out as an area of strength and is now a ~$90m business – yet only ~9% of the customer base has both Network and Endpoint products.
Network appears to be holding up despite slowdown at key peers
Network grew at over 20%, with the key UTM offering +23-24% in Q4. It appears that SOPH has avoided the slowdown in firewall spend affecting key peers PANW, CHKP and FTNT. We think SOPH has benefited from lower datacenter firewall exposure along with its SMB focus; we believe most SOPH customers were less prone to the panic buying and subsequent ‘hangover’ amongst enterprise clients over the last 2-3 years.
Recent guidance and our forecasts
In the trading statement, SOPH guided for $630m billings, and Cash EBITDA and uFCF to be ‘above’ $148m and $110m. We forecast $630m, $154m and $115m, respectively.
Price target to 350p, reiterate Buy
Our target price of 350p is based on 1) our target multiples of 3.5x EV/Sales, ~15x EV/uFCF, 2) our DCF-based valuation. Key downside risks include stronger competition in the midmarket IT Security space and worsening macro impacting IT spending.

BE11:50am

@Littleclenches: yes! Indeed. I meant Wednesday when I typed Friday.

BE11:51am

Sophos reports Wednesday.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

And Neil Campling of Aviate kicks some numbers around on the ransomware thing and the market opportunity of monetising management paranoia.

BE11:52am

Did I say Aviate? I meant Northern Trust. Sorry, I'm not on today.

BE11:52am

Only 7% of organizations are extremely confident of their IT security protocol according to a 2017 Cyber Security Survey by Check Point of 1,900 U.S. IT security professionals. The same survey revealed that 81% of organizations had security concerns. And this before the very high profile “WannaCry” ransomware attack which paralysed the likes of the UK’s NHS and Germany’s national rail network on Friday. It is now known that at least 100K organizations across 150 countries have already been affected (source; EuroPol) in what has been described as the biggest ever cyber attack. China alone has, according to state media, seen 29K institutions hit including universities, hospital, shopping malls, railway stations and gas stations.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Ransomware as a Service (RaaS) appears to be growing as the preferred method of attack by cyber criminals, as evidenced by the 167-fold growth in the number of ransomware attacks between 2015 and 2016 (source: SonicWall). Traditional solutions can often only identify potential threats but not offer prevention. Real time breach prevention protocols are required to protect against threats as they emerge in the cyber security arms race and a constant cat and mouse game between security teams and cyber criminals. 2014 was the last year of a series of mega breaches with the high profile Target breach (40M credit and debit cards stolen) seen as a trigger for corporations to increase focus on IT security solutions. Indeed a Ponemon Institute study revealed that 61% of respondents (735 IT security experts) saw their IT security budgets increase by an average of 34% after the Target attack. We wouldn’t be surprised if the scale and scope of “WannaCry” leads to another spike in IT security solutions and associated revenue spend.

BE11:52am

"Ransomware as a Service (RaaS)" ....... That's great. I hope that catches on.

BE11:53am

The rising threat of CyberCrime and the pressing needs for IT Security solutions remains front and centre of every CTO and the biggest risk to the surge of the digital economy. Sophos is our preferred way to express this threat/opportunity. Sophos targets the small and mid-market where the needs for robust IT security solutions are likely most pressing and underserved in our view. (Sophos has just c.11% revenues mix to large enterprises with c.56% serving the mid-market and c.26% the SMB market.) We see a shift in trend of corporates’ security needs away from traditional on premise security to more software, virtual, SaaS, and public cloud-deployed models. Sophos has been expanding into these next gen solutions with server protection for virtual (VMWare, Microsoft Hyper-V) and IaaS (Amazon AWS, Microsoft Azure) environments. With a global channel network of over 26K partners, we see Sophos as well placed to capture significant growth opportunities. Billings is the most focused metric for the sector and Sophos should be able to continue to post impressive billings growth given the demand drivers in the industry. Sophos report interim results on Wednesday. We remain buyers.

We upgrade Lloyds from Hold to Buy driven by 4 areas: 1) following 4 quarters of successive reductions, NII is now growing; 2) though below the line charges are not over (we forecast another £1bn of PPI + £1bn for other redress) the worst should be past and we expect statutory earnings to trend to u/l by 2019, 3) Dividends: the strong 1Q17 CET1 of 14.3% and maintained guidance of 13% req means that Lloyds should be in a position to pay 4.65p dividends in 2017e, rising to 5.9p in 2019e, or consider buybacks. 4) Valuation: Lloyds is trading at a 1.26x TNAV for 6-7% yield and 12.3% RoTE vs. Europe at 1.13x TNAV, 10% RoTE and 5-6% div yield.
